{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3376257,"name":"Jack","username":"JackOutTheBox","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jackoutthebox/{size}/161568_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-29T01:44:40.260Z","cooked":"

For the offseason I plan on testing how wide it is worth making wheel treads for swerve drive, but I’m curious if anybody has already determined this as I haven’t found any satisfactory results so far. I know that while wider treads should improve traction, they also increase how much the wheels scrub against the ground. Has anyone already figured out the point at which diminishing returns are experienced in the gains in traction?

the new-ish Coussens swerve(what the MAXSwerve and SwerveXS are based off) uses a 2" wide billet wheel this year. i believe it’s 33 killer bees who made it

edit: 33 did not use the coussens swerve this year

33 used SwerveX this past season (2024).

8096 used the latest version of my module that you linked above, which did feature 2in wide roughtop tread purchased from WCP. We were very happy with the performance of the wider tread, both in the traction and the longevity it had. I do not have any hard data for comparing this at all, but the wider tread is something we definitely would like to continue having in the future, and was a main reason for continuing to use the module instead of the Maxswerve or SwerveXS (SwerveXS came out just before the season and we were already committed to the latest module as well).

JackOutTheBox:

I plan on testing how wide it is worth making wheel treads for swerve drive, but I’m curious if anybody has already determined this as I haven’t found any satisfactory results so far.

Sounds very interesting. It would be great if you could share your results.

For typical rough top belt tread, the largest factor we have seen with regards to traction is tread wear. As the tread wears down and becomes smoother the traction is significantly reduced. When tread width and wheel diameter are increased you are increasing the contact patch of the tread. This will result in the tread being stressed less. Also, increasing tread width and wheel diameter increases the amount of tread material in total.

As an example a 4"D X 1.5"W wheel will have double the total tread material as a 3"D X 1"W wheel. The tread material will also be less stressed due to the larger contact patch. This results in tread life of the larger wheel being well more than double of the small wheel, resulting in much longer lasting “good” traction.

The increased scrub of the wheel when steering is pretty far from being a concern with reasonable tread widths. Especially when full sized steering motors are used.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-04-29T06:20:52.362Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":349,"readers_count":348,"score":194.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464826,"topic_slug":"ideal-tread-width-for-swerve-drive","display_username":"Patrick Woolfenden","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30603,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2910 | swervedrive.com"},"post_url":"/t/ideal-tread-width-for-swerve-drive/464826/4","custom_user_title":"2910 | swervedrive.com","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"call_me_hand","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376410,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-29T12:51:08.670Z","cooked":"
PatrickW:

The increased scrub of the wheel when steering is pretty far from being a concern with reasonable tread widths. Especially when full sized steering motors are used.

Wheel scrub power draw is way down the list, I agree, especially considering the 2767 style dualy swerve seems happy scrubbing two ~1inch wheels with about an inch between them (not quite 3 inches of face width, butclose enough in terms of the forces)
